parameter 1: The 1982 broadcast version is trimmed to 25 minutes.
parameter 2: There are various existing versions of this film. However, the one thought to be closest to the version premiered in Vienna in 1924 is a print found in 1975 by Lillian Kiesler, widow of Frederick Kiesler, who arranged the premiere. This version has been preserved by Anthology Film Archives of New York.
parameter 3: The 18-rated UK release of this film was cut by 4 minutes 56 seconds by the BBFC.
parameter 4: In the mid-1990s, a UK video label known as Crusader Video, produced an English dub with regional British accents used for the characters. It was edited for nudity and sexual references. In 2003, a newer dub was produced by ADV Films in the US, with a few characters ironically sporting southern-US accents. This newer dub is unedited and was released on DVD in both the US and the UK.
parameter 5: The version aired on the Cartoon Network are cut and fade to black after Yosemite Sam says "mare?" The original ending has Bugs Bunny asking "anyone for Russian Roulette." Sam and Bugs take turn firing the gun. The gun doesn't fire on Sam, but when Bugs fires, it goes off, but Bugs says he missed. The bullet did hit Sam, to which he says "I hate that rabbit."
parameter 6: The 18-rated UK release of this film was cut by 4 minutes 56 seconds by the BBFC.
parameter 7: The version aired on the Cartoon Network are cut and fade to black after Yosemite Sam says "mare?" The original ending has Bugs Bunny asking "anyone for Russian Roulette." parameter 8: In the mid-1990s, a UK video label known as Crusader Video, produced an English dub with regional British accents used for the characters. It was edited for nudity and sexual references. In 2003, a newer dub was produced by ADV Films in the US, with a few characters ironically sporting southern-US accents. This newer dub is unedited and was released on DVD in both the US and the UK.
parameter 9: For the original release, the "Walt Disney presents" title card is the start of the film. For the DVD release, the theme has a slight musical extension to fill in a new time gap made by a shorter version of the Walt Disney logo, which is perfectly in sync with the music. After the logo ends, the Walt Disney title card appears, and the film starts normally.
parameter 10: In the mid-1990s, a UK video label known as Crusader Video, produced an English dub with regional British accents used for the characters. This newer dub is unedited and was released on DVD in both the US and the UK.

parameter 15: The version shown on BBC Television fades to black after Bugs asks "Anyone for Russian Roulette?" and completely omits the closing gags with the gun.
parameter 16: There are various existing versions of this film. However, the one thought to be closest to the version premiered in Vienna in 1924 is a print found in 1975 by Lillian Kiesler, widow of Frederick Kiesler, who arranged the premiere. This version has been preserved by Anthology Film Archives of New York.
parameter 17: The version shown on BBC Television fades to black after Bugs asks "Anyone for Russian Roulette?" and completely omits the closing gags with the gun.
parameter 18: Originally released in US theatres with a NC-17 rating; video version is edited and is rated R.
parameter 19: 1 minute and 1 second of bloody injuries and weapons were removed from the UK cinema release to obtain a 12A certificate instead of an uncut 15.

parameter 22: In an alternate ending, Kate Wheeler ('Cate Blanchett' (qv)) is holding Joe's ('Bruce Willis' (qv)) and Terry's ('Billy Bob Thornton' (qv)) hands while watching the wedding, and she is pregnant. Letting the viewer speculate which man is the father.
